Award.AwardTitle: Tojolabal (SIL CODE: toj) (Maya) Language Documentation Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tojolabal Maya is spoken by several thousand people in the Chiapas state of Mexico, near the border with Guatemala. Although still vital, the language is subject to many pressures. Many of the speakers have moved to urban centers in Mexico and the U.S., some by choice, some due to social and political conflicts. Both groups often abandon their native tongue. With support from National Science Foundation, Dr. N. Louanna Furbee will establish a Tojolabal Language Documentation Center and train a community-based Tojolabal team to document the language. Linguists from abroad and native speakers will collaborate directly, intertwining their understandings of linguistic phenomena from different but mutually informative perspectives. Workshops given by visiting experts, including indigenous scholars, will impart the skills of language documentation and linguistic analysis.

This Center will provide new educational opportunities for community members who have had limited access to formal education in the past. Later, the primary team will establish secondary centers in selected Tojolabal communities through which they can extend this education to other speakers. By establishing literacy programs, literary activities, research projects, and language documentation efforts, the team hopes to increase the profile of the language and the perceived value of speaking it.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A noteworthy aspect of the “Tojolabal (SIL CODE: toj) (Maya) Language Documentation Project” is that it attempted to form a group of native speakers of the Tojol-ab’al language into a skilled team to document and revitalize their endangered Mayan language, providing a model for other projects. Tojol-ab’al is spoken in Chiapas, Mexico, where educational opportunities were limited, so the team of two women and three men had limited formal education, and all were linguistically naïve. They were trained through workshops presented by experts. Their successes exceeded expectations.

  Specific goals of the project were to (1) form the Tojol-ab’al Language Documentation Center (TLDC); (2) train an all-tojol-ab’al documentation team; (3) document Tojol-ab’al in as many contexts as possible (using audio, photo, and video recordings of narrative, conversation, life histories, community histories, ritual and everyday language); (4) form a network of secondary community documentation centers (CDCs) in selected Tojo-ab’al-speaking villages and train their staffs through workshops prepared by TLDC; (5) provide educational opportunities; (6) teach Tojol-ab’al literacy; (7) encourage growth of Tojol-ab’al literature; and (8) engage in research, publication, and professional interaction.

    The TLDC documented more than 200 examples of Tojol-ab’al during the grant period. Staff gave presentations in regional, national, and international professional venues. They participated in a weekly Tojol-ab’al radio program. They organized meetings, published articles and books, spearheaded normalization of the writing system for Tojol-ab’al, defined indigenous intellectual property rights, and created a code of ethical behavior to guide activities. Their greatest contribution was to inject an indigenous perspective into linguistic discussion, creating a form of indigenous linguistics. TLDC (http://sssat.missouri.edu) demonstrated that nonprofessionals can profoundly affect the conduct of language and culture documentation and revitalization programs when they have skills-based training and opportunities for interacting in professional forums.

  In 2008, TLDC pursued creating a consensus set of conventions for writing Tojol-ab'al. The Instituto Nacional de Lenguas Indígenas (INALI) took up this quest, and by 2011, most institutions and writers of Tojol-ab’al had agreed upon a system for writing the language, which Mexican federal agencies accepted, and INALI published and promulgated. In 2010, TLDC formulated a statement of ethical practice and indigenous property rights, and by year’s end, other projects began similar efforts.  TLDC also cooperated in creating a 2-semester course in the Tojol-ab’al language for the National Intercultural University of Chiapas, published in 2 volumes, and supervised UNICH students for their social service.

   The TLDC also developed ‘metamodels’ of topics in Tojol-ab’al grammar (for evidentials, for syntacto-semantically related verb sets, and for conjunct and independent verbs) and used these in linguistic research on those topics. Metamodels are co-created intermediate models of explanation accessible to both experts and non-experts. Through them, linguistically inexperienced native speakers and professional linguists can articulate their understandings of language phenomena. The TLDC presented papers at national and international meetings on conjunct and independent verb forms. They gave papers and published articles that included their analysis of evidentials in Tojol-ab’al.
